Award.AwardTitle: Motives, geometry, and higher category theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
Homotopy theory is the study of properties of mathematical objects which remain invariant under deformation. Historically, homotopy theory emerged from algebraic topology, which is the study of topological spaces (roughly, geometry in which there is a notion of closeness but not distance) through algebraic invariants; gradually, however, it has found applications much more broadly throughout many areas of mathematics, especially algebraic and differential geometry, and has many interesting connections to physics. Part of the reason for this is that focusing on deformation-invariant properties of mathematical objects makes both classifications and calculations much more tractable. The interaction goes both ways; recently algebraic and geometric methods have found powerful applications in homotopy theory, and much recent research has been concerned with the algebro-geometric and higher-categorical nature of homotopical objects, illuminating many structural aspects and inspiring further interactions between these various mathematical disciplines.

The purpose of this project is to employ algebro-geometric and higher-categorical techniques in the study of algebraic topology and homotopy theory. The first goal is to study algebraic K-theory and related theories such as topological Hochschild homology, as well as more general motives arising in algebraic geometry, with emphasis on developing computational methods through identification of localization sequences. The second aims to classify thick subcategories of certain stable higher categories, especially those which arise in geometry by formation of perfect complexes over various classes of derived schemes. The third involves elliptic cohomology and is concerned with the explicit description of the elliptic cohomology of various orbifolds and is an important example of the not yet fully understood stable homotopy theory of orbifolds, also known as global stable homotopy theory, another subject of much recent attention. The final goal is to understand the units of a derived scheme using the emerging tools of derived algebraic geometry, in particular the Picard and Brauer groups and their higher categorical analogues and possible connections to topological field theories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Geometry is one of the oldest and deepest areas of mathematics. The axiomatic approach to geometry was pioneered by Euclid around 300 BC. However, Euclidean geometry is insufficient to describe our physical world; moreover, there is no a priori mathematical reason why space shouldn't be curved, or exotic in other ways. This became a major theme in mathematics and physics as early as the 19th century, and by the beginning of the 20th century various flavors (algebraic, analytic, differential) of very general geometries had been developed, along with the notion of abstract space, together with algebraic means of studying and classifying these newfound objects (which are still of central import in theoretical physics). Still a century later, there has been substantial mathematical progress in the foundations of geometry, ranging from noncommutative geometry (necessitated by quantum theory), the conjectural theory of motives, and the advent of higher category theory. This project is concerned with obtaining a rigorous understanding of what these new foundation are and how they relate to one another.

Category theory is the language of abstract mathematical objects, and higher category theory incorporates homotopy theory, which is roughly the geometric study of deformable objects, directly into its syntax. It should be no surprise, therefore, that this new formalism has already found interesting and unexpected connections to both geometry and physics. One of the major unifying themes is the theory of noncommutative motives, which is to noncommutative (quantum) geometry which commutative motives is to commutative (classical) geometry. The motive of a geometric object is roughly an algebraic reflection of the object which contains its essential homological or homotopical behaviour. Motives collectively form a means of distilling precisely the desired information from a geometric context. In particular, noncommutative motives are a means of understanding important algebraic invariants such as K-theory, Hochschild, and cyclic homology.

The PI, together with collaborators Antieau and Barthel, contribute to the study of localization in noncommutative motives and use this technology to disprove a conjecture of Rognes regarding chromatic redshift in K-theory. Together with Antieau and (separately) Lawson, the PI uses the methods of Galois descent to calculate important and classical algebraic invariants of rings equipped with a homotopy coherent addition and multiplication. Results internal to higher category theory itself are obtained, which will have future applications. Together with Haugseng, the PI developes the theory of enriched higher operads, and together with Haugsend and Nikolaus, the PI studies free fibrations in the higher categorical context. Finally, work of the PI and Bunke studies the transfer in differential cohomology with applications to differential algebraic K-theory.
